Nanochemistry and Ecology Laboratory, National University of Science and Technology MISiS Leninsky Prospect 4 Moscow 119991 Russian Federation A new nickel phyllosilicate (Ni-PhySi) catalyst was synthesized and used for the selective hydrogenation of unsaturated compounds to alkenes. Nickel phyllosilicate catalyst was synthesized by deposition-precipitation with urea method and characterized by TPR-H2, N2 adsorption, XRD, FTIR and HRTEM methods. Nickel phyllosilicate showed an enhanced catalytic activity compared with supported nickel oxide and Ni Raney in hydrogenation of unsaturated compounds at mild conditions with the selectivity toward C = C bond formation higher than 86%. Moreover, nickel phyllosilicate demonstrated a great stability during at least seven cycles of reuse. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Nickel phyllosilicate Selective hydrogenation Phenylacetylene Styrene Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction The selective hydrogenation of unsaturated CC to C = C bonds is an important industrial process for the production of petrochemicals, fragrances, pharmaceuticals and flavor compounds, which plays an important role for society developments [1–3]. Generally, triple bond hydrogenation over the metal catalysts leads to the formation of alkane as reaction of alkene reduction typically proceeds faster than alkyne hydrogenation (Scheme 1 ) [4]. Thus, the search of the suitable catalyst allowing preferentially obtain double bond product is still in the focus of the researchers. Traditionally, palladium and platinum are the preferred metals for alkyne hydrogenation due to their great ability for hydrogen adsorption [5–8]. A number of papers on the hydrogenation of unsaturated compounds published over the past 10 years are devoted to the modification of palladium-containing catalysts by varying the carrier, synthesis conditions and catalyst composition, as well as the study of synergism in bimetallic catalysts [9]. The main drawbacks of Pd catalysts are high price of the noble metal and low selectivity, which is due to high metal reactivity and fast formation of the alkane in the reaction mixture. Leviness et al. reported the possibility of direct ethane formation from acetylene over palladium catalyst without the formation of intermediate alkene [10]. In work of Markov et al. it was noted that styrene selectivity greatly depends on size of Pd nanoparticles [11] and it decreases a lot with the use of supported palladium species below 8 nm. In recent years, special attention has been paid to the development of catalysts for the selective hydrogenation of unsaturated compounds with an ultra-low noble metal content [12,13] or to the systems without precious metals, in particular those based on Fe, Cu and Ni nanoparticles [14–19]. Nickel catalysts are the most affordable and versatile catalytic materials for hydrogenation of alkynes, which do not contain noble metals [20]. Ni is inexpensive compared to Pd or Pt with the same d10 outer shell configuration and has various oxidation states (0, +1, +2 and + 3) and is more nucleophilic due to its small size as a ‘first-row’ transition metal [21]. However, despite the great activity of nickel catalysts, it is always challenging to achieve high alkyne conversion and avoid over-hydrogenating. Shittu et al. reported selectivity toward styrene close to 100% at phenylacetylene conversion of ∼50% but increase of conversion lead to drastically decrease of styrene selectivity [22]. The similar effect was noted by Chen et al. [23]. Over monometallic Ni/SiO2 catalyst drop in selectivity of styrene was detected at substrate conversion higher 70%. The addition of the metal modificator such as Co and Zn helped to improve styrene selectivity. Nickel Raney is by far the most often used nickel catalyst due to its high hydrogenating activity, however, it has a number of disadvantages, such as ferromagnetic properties that exclude the use of magnetic mixing, it is pyrophoric, low-selective and is quickly deactivated [24]. Currently, phyllosilicate materials gain a lot of interest in catalysis field due to the great dispersion of the supported metal, the high specific surface area and to the strong interaction between the supported transition metal and the carrier [19,25]. Phyllosilicate structures typically consist of alternating parallel layers of silica and metal (Cu, Ni, Co, Fe). In the silica layer, the tetrahedral unit of (SiO4)2− shares four oxygens to form a hexagonal ring structure, forming the basic unit of (Si2O5)2−. The metal layer forms an octahedral MO6 structure, the oxygen at the center mainly constitutes an OH group, and the oxygens at the end are shared with the hexagonal ring structure of the tetrahedral (SiO4)2− unit [26]. When nickel phyllosilicate is reduced under hydrogen conditions, the ions (Ni2+) inside the unreduced phyllosilicate serve as a fixed position of the nanoparticles (Ni0), strengthening the metal-support interaction and preventing their sintering [25]. Nickel phyllosilicate (Ni-PhySi) is widely studied in a number of catalytic reactions, such as methane steam reforming [27], CO2 conversion [28], photocatalysis [29,30], hydrogenolysis of esters [31] and water purification [32] both as a catalyst and as a carrier. However, the catalytic potential of nickel phyllosilicate in the reactions of selective hydrogenation of unsaturated compounds has not yet been studied. Thus, the objective of the present paper is to study the catalytic activity of nickel catalysts with a phyllosilicate structure in the selective hydrogenation of CC to C = C bond in various aromatic and aliphatic substrates under mild reaction conditions and to compare them with commercial samples and traditional nickel oxide catalysts. Experimental Synthesis of catalysts In this work, silica-supported nickel catalysts were prepared using two different methods. A commercial Ni-Raney catalyst (Acros Organics) was used to compare the catalytic properties of nickel-containing catalysts. Nickel phyllosilicate (Ni-PhySi) material was prepared by Ni(NO3)2 deposition–precipitation, predominantly on the outer surface of the commercial SiO2 support, using thermal hydrolysis of urea (DPU method). For the typical preparation procedure, deionized water (41.5 mL) and a 1 M Ni(NO3)2 solution (8.5 mL) were mixed at room temperature to obtain clear solution. Then, a commercial silica support powder (SBET = 250 m2*g−1, Saint-Gobain) was added to the solution under vigorous stirring. After 15 min urea (3.1 g) was introduced into the suspension and the slurry was stirred for 10 h at 90 °C. After that, the precipitate was separated by centrifugation, the catalyst sample was triple washed with 20 mL of deionized water, dried at 110 °C and calcined at 300 °C in air for 3 h. The catalyst sample obtained by the DPU method was marked as 10Ni-PhySi where 10 is the mass percentage of Ni. A Ni-containing catalyst with a metal content of 5 wt.% was synthesized by a analogous technique in order to compare the catalytic properties of the samples. More details on the method of preparation of catalysts by the DPU method can be found in our previous work [33]. The supported NiO nanoparticles with the nickel content of 10% wt. on the same SiO2 carrier were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation (IP) method. The detailed description of the procedure is provided in Supporting Materials. Catalyst characterization The phase composition of the samples was identified by X-ray diffraction (XRD) method using an ARL X'TRA diffractometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific). The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured by a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 Plus System. Pore size distributions for mesopores were determined by the Barret-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method, while the micropore size distribution was calculated according to the Horwath-Kawazoe model. The electronic states of the catalysts elements were investigated by FTIR method using a Bruker ALPHA II spectrometer and by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) technique using a PHI5000VersaProbeII spectrometer. The catalysts reducibility was studied by H2 temperature-programmed reduction (TPR-H2) method. The morphological properties of the catalysts were investigated by HRTEM method using a JEOL JEM-2100 transmission electron microscope. Detailed descriptions of the characterization procedures are given in Supporting Materials. Hydrogenation of unsaturated compounds The catalytic properties of the prepared catalysts were investigated in the liquid-phase hydrogenation of phenylacetylene to styrene with molecular hydrogen using a stainless-steel «Parr» autoclave system (100 ml) with a probe-withdrawing valve. In a typical experimental procedure, a 0.2 M substrate solution in ethanol (30 ml) with undecane as an internal standard was used with the catalyst mass (100 mg) of so nsyb/nMe ratio was equal to 35. Reactions were carried out under H2 pressure of 1.5 MPa with the temperature varied in the range 100 - 140 °C at the stirring rate of 500 rpm and 1 hour of reaction duration. Reaction products were analysed by Chromatec Crystal GC using the ZB-5 capillary column (30 m x 0.53 mm x 1.50 μm) and a flame-ionization detector (FID) with an internal standard method and the column temperature 80 °C. Results and discussion Physico-chemical properties of the catalysts Supported nickel-containing catalysts were obtained by the DPU and IP methods. The catalysts obtained after the calcination stage had a different color: the samples prepared by the DPU method had a light green staining (Fig. 1 a), while the samples synthesized by the IP method had a black coloring (Fig. 1b), which is probably related to the formation of the different nickel phases. In order to investigate the textural and physico-chemical properties of prepared samples, a series of methods was used. XRD analysis of the 10Ni-PhySi catalyst has shown that the peaks positions at 26.7°, 33.7°, 39.7° and 60.9° (Fig. 2 a) coincides with the literature data, i.e., peaks positions of (103), (110), (200) and (300) planes, respectively, for the pyrophyllite structure of nickel phyllosilicate (Ni3Si4O10(OH)2) (JCPDS 49–1859) [34,35]. The wide diffraction peak at 22° is characteristic for amorphous SiO2 [36]. It is worth to note that XRD signals have a low intensity, which might be due to the low phase crystallinity [37] or due to formation of nanoparticles of a small size. The XRD pattern of the sample prepared by the IP method (Fig. 2a) manifests signals of cubic nickel oxide NiO (JCPDS # 47–1049) [38,39]. Thus, the deposition-precipitation with urea method allows one to obtain catalysts with the phyllosilicate structure, while the impregnation method leads to formation of a nickel oxide phase. The TPR-H2 method was used to investigate the reducibility of prepared catalysts. The TPR profile of the sample obtained by the IP method demonstrates the first peak referring to the reduction of small nickel oxide particles on the catalyst surface (Fig. 2b). The large peak in the temperature range of 300–450 °C most likely belongs to the reduction of nickel oxide to the metallic phase [40]. The shoulder of the reduction peak at high temperatures (>500 °C) can be attributed to the reduction of nickel oxide in narrow pores or channels of the SiO2 support. The TPR curve of the catalyst obtained by the DPU method demonstrates a shift in the peaks of the formation of nickel metal to higher temperatures. Most likely, this is due to the formation of the nickel phyllosilicate phase, which is characterized by the strong interaction of nickel oxide with the SiO2 structure, as a result of which the reduction of nickel oxide nanoparticles closely bounded with the support is much more difficult and requires an increase of the reduction temperature. A similar effect was noted by Chen and co-authors [41], where the presence of a wide high-temperature reduction peak in the region of 670–720 °C was found for the series of Ni phyllosilicate catalysts. BET specific surface area analysis of the samples has shown the decrease of the SBET value of the 10NiO-IP catalyst along with a decrease of the micro- and mesopores volume (Table 1 ). This is probably caused by filling of pores with a metal precursor solution and therefore with deposition of nickel oxide phase inside the SiO2 pores [42]. The formation of small macropore volume might be caused by partial collapse of micro- and mesopores during the calcination step. One the contrary, the increase of the SBET value of the 10Ni-PhySi sample was observed along with the increase of the micropore volume (Table 1). This phenomenon was noted by a number of researchers [43,44] and was probably caused by the creation of additional defects in the SiO2 structure due to formation of the phyllosilicate phase. It was shown by N2 adsorption-desorption analysis that both catalysts and SiO2 support exhibit IV type adsorption isotherms, which are typical for materials with a mesoporous structure (Fig. 2c) [45]. The hysteresis loops observed for the 10NiO-IP and 10Ni-PhySi samples rather belong to the H3 type, which is characterized by the presence of different porous structures [40]. The position of N2 adsorption curves for the 10NiO-IP and 10Ni-PhySi catalysts, which are slightly lower and higher than the SiO2 curve, respectively, also indicates the change of the specific surface area depending on the catalyst preparation method. The character of the pore size distribution varies insignificantly (Fig. 2d). A shoulder appears on the curve of the 10Ni-PhySi sample, associated with the creation of additional micropores due to the formation of a phyllosilicate structure. At the same time, there is a slight shift of the 10NiO-IP catalyst curve towards wider pores. As noted earlier, this is probably due to the partial filling and blocking of the narrow pores of the support as a result of metal deposition by the impregnation method. Studies of N2-adsorption-desorption of the 10Ni-PhySi sample revealed: (i) the formation of a new phase with a high specific surface area, which increases the specific surface area of the initial SiO2 carrier from 244 to 282 m2/g (Table 1); (ii) a wide bimodal distribution of mesopores of the formed new phase in size with two definite maxima at 4.3 nm and 10 nm instead of a narrow monomodal distribution with a maximum at 10 nm for the carrier (Fig. 2d); (iii) the presence of micropores 1–3 nm in size in the structure of the new phase of the phyllosilicate. Fig. 3 illustrates FTIR spectra of the 10Ni-PhySi and 10NiO-IP catalysts. The bands at 469 and 805 cm−1 are assigned to the vibrations of Ni-O-Si species and the tetrahedral Si-O mode, respectively, which appeared in both 10NiO-IP and 10Ni-PhySi catalysts [46]. However, the band at 672 cm−1 is observed only for 10Ni-PhySi sample, which can be attributed to the δ-OH vibrations, characteristic feature of the well-formed Ni phyllosilicate phase [25]. The FTIR spectra both of the samples show an absorption band at 1105 cm−1 and a large shoulder at 1213 cm−1 assigned to Si-O-Si asymmetric stretching vibrations [47]. Moreover, the broad absorption band in the range of 3600–3200 cm−1 and the band 1637 cm−1, correspond to the OH stretching vibrations of adsorbed water and silanol groups, and bending vibrations of –OH groups, respectively, observed for all the samples [48]. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) for the calcined 10NiO-IP and 10Ni-PhySi catalysts were recorded to analyze the chemical states of the active Ni species (Fig. 4 ). Two main peaks in the spectra of 10NiO-IP located at 854.1 and 856.1 eV represent Ni2+ species of nickel oxide. Similar data were previously described by Yang et al. [49], where authors noted that the first peak can be attributed to the large nickel oxide particles without interaction with a silica support, while the second peak can be assigned to well-dispersed NiO particles with strong metal oxide-support interaction. The peaks at 860.9 and 864.8 eV can be assigned as satellite peaks present due to the electron shake-up effect [50,51]. In the spectra of the 10Ni-PhySi sample, the shift of the peaks toward larger binding energis can be observed. This effect can be explained by the strong interaction of Ni2+ species with SiO2 due to phyllosilicate structure formation. The presence of two peaks can be referred to the existence of two types of nickel phyllosilicates species: 1:1 nickel phyllosilicate and 2:1 nickel phyllosilicate [52,53]. The peaks at 861.9 and 867.1 eV can be assigned as satellite peaks. Fig. 5 depicts the clear difference in the textural properties of the catalysts obtained by different methods. In the HRTEM images of the sample obtained by the impregnation method (a), the structure of nickel oxide is distinguishable with an interlayer distance of 2.60 Å, which coincides with the literature data for nickel oxide interlayer distance of the (210) plane [54]. The HRTEM micrographs of the catalyst obtained by the DPU method (b) show the “fibrous” microstructure of the sample, which is characteristic of nickel phyllosilicate [55–57]. In a work of Wang et al. [58] it was noted that this fibrous texture of nickel phyllosilicate stabilizes Ni nanoparticles in general and during the catalytic process in particular. Catalytic performance The selective semi-hydrogenation of phenylacetylene to styrene was chosen as a model reaction of alkyne hydrogenation in order to investigate the nickel phyllosilicate catalytic activity. The reaction proceeded at hydrogen pressure of 1.5 MPa while the experiment temperature varied in the range 100 - 140 °C. A plot of the changes of products distribution on the reaction time over the nickel-containing catalyst at temperature of 120 °C and hydrogen pressure of 1.5 MPa is presented in Fig. 6 . As can be seen, the curves of the dependences of the concentrations of the initial reactant and the reaction products are differ in character. The impregnated calcined sample (10NiO-IP) containing the nickel oxide phase demonstrated relatively low hydrogenation activity with phenylacetylene conversion of only 27% in 60 min of the reaction, while the selectivity to styrene does not exceed 70% (Fig. 6a). The additional reduction of the 10NiO-IP catalyst in H2 flow, which resulted in the formation of Ni0 metal nanoparticles, leads to increase of hydrogenating activity, however, the main product at full phenylacetylene conversion was ethylbenzene. On the reduced 10Ni0-IP catalyst, ethylbenzene and styrene are formed simultaneously, starting from the ∼35% PA conversion (Fig. 6b). A similar t trend was observed on the commercial Ni-Raney catalyst (Fig. 6c). On the 10Ni-PhySi catalyst, the ethylbenzene amount formed at the same PA conversion is lower than that on the reduced Ni catalyst, indicating a lower rate of ethylbenzene formation from styrene (Fig. 6d). A smoother character of the curves after the complete PA conversion also indicates a lower rate of styrene hydrogenation to ethylbenzene on the 10Ni-PhySi catalyst compared to the reduced Ni catalyst. As a result, the selectivity to styrene for the 10Ni-PhySi catalyst is higher than that for the 10Ni0-IP catalyst. The cupola-like shape of the dependence of the styrene concentration on the reaction time over 10Ni0-IP catalyst indicates the consecutive occurrence of reactions of PA hydrogenation to styrene and styrene hydrogenation to ethylbenzene. The similar catalytic behavior was noted on 10Ni-PhySi sample, but the hydrogenation of styrene started when the amount of phenylacetylene in the reaction mixture become very low (lower than 0.04 mol/L). The linear dependence of ethylbenzene concentration after the complete PA conversion (as in the presence of 10NiO-IP sample) indicates the zero-reaction order with respect to styrene. The same results were observed in the presence of a commercial Ni Raney catalyst (Fig. 7 a). Catalytic hydrogenation of PA over Ni Raney (Fig. 7a) and 10Ni0-IP (Fig. 6a) catalysts showed full conversion of the substrate for 1 hour with 0% selectivity toward styrene; the only reaction product was ethylbenzene. The high reactivity of these catalysts in hydrogenation reaction was noted earlier by other authors: predominant formation of ethylbenzene is explained by over hydrogenation of phenylacetylene which leads to further reduction of styrene. Both Raney Ni and 10Ni0-IP catalysts mainly contains reduced nickel nanoparticles as an active phase. In one hand, the use of metallic Ni can greatly facilitate the hydrogen splitting and formation of an active hydrogen species. On the other hand, it leads to low selectivity for the target product styrene due to its competitive adsorption. Thus, the superior catalytic performance was observed over the 10Ni-PhySi catalyst with 89.6% of phenylacetylene conversion and 90.1% styrene selectivity (Fig. 7a). A few papers were published describing semi-hydrogenation of phenylacetylene over monometallic nickel catalysts. Yang et al. [59] reported phenylacetylene reduction over nickel silicide catalysts of different compositions. The maximum conversion achieved was close to 70% with styrene selectivity of 90%. In the work of Golubina and co-authors [60] phenylacetylene hydrogenation reaction was performed in the presence of nickel nanoparticles supported by detonated nanodiamonds carriers. Styrene selectivity was strongly dependent on conversion level; on Ni/ND_300 catalyst the rise of conversion up to 60% lead to decrease of styrene selectivity from 100% to 80%. However, up to date no published results were found about alkyne hydrogenation over nickel phyllosilicate materials. At the same time, the composition of the samples obtained by the DPU method had a strong effect on the conversion of the substrate and target product selectivity. Increasing the loading of Ni by 5 wt.% to 10 wt.% increases the catalytic activity (Fig. 7a), while the styrene selectivity stays at the same level. After the screening of catalysts, the influence of the reaction temperature on the catalytic activity over the superior catalyst was investigated. As shown in Fig. 7b, the increase in the reaction temperature greatly effects on catalyst activity. At 100 °C, the conversion was as low as 38.1% on 10Ni-PhySi and the selectivity to styrene of 75.3% for 1 h was observed. At the reaction temperature of 120 °C the highest PA conversion (∼90%) with the highest styrene selectivity (∼90%) was achieved. A further increase of temperature to 140 °C leads to an increase of PA conversion, but at the same time the selectivity of styrene formation decreases due to the rapid formation of a by-product of complete hydrogenation – ethylbenzene. The stability of the 10Ni-PhySi catalyst was another important parameter to evaluate the catalyst properties, so the possibility of the 10Ni-PhySi sample reuse was also examined in our study. The spent catalysts were collected by centrifugation after each experimental run for 5 cycles without washing with a solvent for the next recycle test. According to the results, it was found that the 10Ni-PhySi catalyst demonstrated the styrene selectivity above 80% after each cycle with a slight decrease in phenylacetylene conversion from 89.6 to 75% after the five recycle tests (Fig. 8 ). The sixth cycle was carried out after washing the catalyst in acetone, which led to an increase in selectivity and conversion, probably due to the removal of adsorbed substances on the surface of the catalyst. The absence of the nickel nanoparticles leaching from the support surface was verified by qualitative test of the reaction medium to Ni2+ ions with 0.1 M NH4OH. Moreover, after the catalyst separation from the reaction mixture hydrogenation was continued and the analysis results showed that there was no increase of conversion or selectivity. As we see from catalytic test results, the phenylacetylene conversion over the nickel oxide catalyst was quite low and was less than 30% in 1 hour of the reaction, while on reduced nickel nanoparticles, we observed over-hydrogenation with the formation of ethylbenzene. It was noted that further hydrogenation of the formed styrene continues because of the strong adsorption of the C = C bond on metallic nickel nanoparticles. Nakatsuji et al. [61] also mentioned that the presence of metallic Ni nanoparticles is essential for dissociation of hydrogen during phenylacetylene transformation. Thus, we can conclude that the electronic state of nickel plays the crucial role in the mechanism of phenylacetylene hydrogenation. As phyllosilicate material can be described as silica-metal layered material, it can be characterized by strong interaction between Ni and silica units. We can assume that during the reaction under a hydrogen atmosphere, a partial reduction of Ni2+ ions to Ni0 on the material surface may occur, while the rest of the nickel remains in the oxidized state due to strong interaction with SiO2. The combination of two different types of Ni in the catalysts probably is necessary for the selective styrene formation; metallic Ni centers provide hydrogen dissociation, while Ni2+centers are the active centers for reaction proceeding with, possibly, weaker C = C bond adsorption, which allows for styrene to easily desorb from the catalyst surface avoiding over-hydrogenation. A similar effect was described by Golubina et al. [60] for nanodiamond-supported nickel nanoparticles. Authors observed the formation of two types of Ni species in their catalysts: weakly- and strongly-bonded. Weakly-bonded species were characterized by a lower reduction temperature to metallic Ni. During gas-phase phenylacetylene hydrogenation tests, it was noted that the conversion over weakly bonded NPs leads to formation of ethylbenzene, while over strongly-bonded Ni, the main reaction product was styrene. Additionally, the activity of 10Ni-PhySi catalyst was investigated in the selective hydrogenation of various unsaturated substrates at temperature 120 °C and an Н2 pressure of 1.5 MPа (Table 2 ). Aliphatic alkynes of different geometry (linear and brunched) with the terminal CC group were studied using 2-methyl-3-butyn-2-ol and 1,4-butynediol as starting materials. Worth to note that both of corresponding alkenes, 2-methyl-3-buten-2-ol and 1,4-butenediol, are of great importance in pharmaceutical industry as they widely used as intermediates for the synthesis of vitamins A and E, biologically active compounds, linalool, aroma compounds, and agrochemicals [62–65]. After 1 h of the reactions the conversion achieved 87% and 95% for 2-methyl-3-butyn-2-ol and 1,4-butynediol respectively with the alkenes selectivity higher than 86%. Moreover, selective hydrogenation of aromatic alkynes with the internal CC bond was performed with the use of diphenylacetylene and 2-phenylethinylaniline as the substrates. The conversion values were amounted 97% and 92% respectively with alkenes selectivity more than 90% in both reactions. The comparison of nickel catalysts activity in phenylacetylene hydrogenation with published data is represented in Table 3 . It is well-known that nickel catalysts are generally highly active in hydrogenation reactions, but the selectivity in such processes is still questionable, especially in case of semi-hydrogenation reactions. Thus, the high selectivity toward styrene (above 80%) was detected only at low conversion values [66], as after styrene accumulation in the reaction mixture the complete hydrogenation reaction begins to predominate [68]. Yang et al. [67] achieved a high styrene selectivity with a high conversion level over a 8%NiZn3/AlSBA-15 catalyst, but the reaction proceeded for more than 15 h. In our work, it was shown that nickel phyllosilicate-based catalysts are highly effective in triple bond semi-hydrogenation under relatively mild reaction conditions and at a short experiment time. Thus, it can be concluded that the formation of phyllosilicate phase along with the increased of specific surface area are significantly improve both the catalytic activity of Ni-containing materials and selectivity toward C = C bond formation in unsaturated substrates hydrogenation reactions. Conclusions A new catalytically active material (Ni3Si4O10(OH)2), consisting of a micro-mesoporous phase of Ni phyllosilicate, was synthesized for the first time inside the pores of a commercial carrier of meso‑macroporous silica using a simple urea deposition (DPU) technique. Using a set of physico-chemical methods TPR-H2, N2 adsorption-desorption, FTIR and XRD, the formation of the phyllosilicate phase under mild conditions (90 °C, molar ratio urea: Ni = 10, atmospheric pressure) was proved for 10 h. The superior 10Ni-PhySi catalyst provides selectivity to styrene and stilbene formation over 90% at 120 °C and 1.5 MPa H2 pressure within 1 h, which cannot be achieved over an impregnated 10NiO-IP or Ni Raney catalyst. In addition, the nickel catalyst with the phyllosilicate structure has also demonstrated good stability and excellent catalytic characteristics in the hydrogenation of unsaturated compounds, which indicates a great potential for the production of alkenes on a large scale. coredata.dc:description: A new nickel phyllosilicate (Ni-PhySi) catalyst was synthesized and used for the selective hydrogenation of unsaturated compounds to alkenes. Nickel phyllosilicate catalyst was synthesized by deposition-precipitation with urea method and characterized by TPR-H2, N2 adsorption, XRD, FTIR and HRTEM methods. Nickel phyllosilicate showed an enhanced catalytic activity compared with supported nickel oxide and Ni Raney in hydrogenation of unsaturated compounds at mild conditions with the selectivity toward C = C bond formation higher than 86%. Moreover, nickel phyllosilicate demonstrated a great stability during at least seven cycles of reuse.
coredata.dc:title: A novel catalyst based on nickel phyllosilicate for the selective hydrogenation of unsaturated compounds
